lines.text: Vivian tells me you're not staying, Wolfe.
What do you mean, you're not staying?
Got to get back into town, love. I've got things to do. Listen, I'll take your car, OK. I'm sure someone will give you a lift back in the morning.
Yes, I'm going back myself.
Got things to do, pet.
You are a sod, Wolfe!
What can I do?
What a shame. Still, I hope you'll enter into the spirit of things, Venetia.
I don't know what you're hoping to achieve, except perhaps an orgasm.
Don't be a burke all your life. Take a day off, Sergeant.
Inspector.
Oh it's come through, has it? That's nice. Bit more on your widow's pension.
He's losing a lot of claret, Vic.
It's not our sort... It's not your sort... What I mean is... A bit of robbery these days, I mean, you can't tell.
We're being very erudite today, aren't we? Bit of blazing eloquence there.
No need to collect off Danny for a couple of weeks - reward initiative.
Mr Dakin comes here for our excellent restaurant.
And to collect "the insurance".
I don't quite follow you.
Bollocks, Mr Barzun!

I'm a clerk, and a clerk, Mr Bellamy, is nothing now. Oh just before the war he was important, he gave the orders, he was the one who could rise to 400 a year, little modest saloon by the time he was 40. Your working man stayed at 3 quid a week. Not now, and my wife knows it - she says to our kid, you won't be a failure like your father.
Sounds like a right cow.
Very nice car, Terry. Very good steel.
Boxed in and buggered! What is it?
Toys, Vic, just toys!
Big tough lads.
From the local rugby club.
Yeah, well they'll be short on Saturday.
Fancy living here.
Nice and quiet.
Stupid punters. Telly all the week, screw the wife Saturday.
Pick 'im up, pick 'im up!
It's not our game, is it Vic. We're playing away.
Go and make a phone call, Terry.
Who to?
Your fairy-sodding-godmother - I don't know.
Frank, Frank. We're the boys, aren't we? Aren't we the boys. Always have been, ever since we were kids. Hardly got off our mother's tit when we had 'em quaking down in Hackney.
Here's Benny now. He can tell you.
He's only pulled. He's only pulled a bird. I'd give her one.
Wolfe, I'm so glad you could come, how terrific.
Hello Vivian, this is Venetia.
Hello Venetia. Well we're all drinking in here so do come on through. I do wish you'd been here last night Wolfe, some lovely faces came down.
I know his face, don't I?
Should do, seen it often enough on telly. Stirring the conscience of the nation, he's an MP.
Well he wouldn't get my vote.
It's not your *vote* he's after.
Why don't you go make a cup of tea?
Who's she?
Sssh. It's his gaffe. Only a marquis, isn't he. Influencing friends and making people.

Vic Dakin has shot and killed Edgar Lowis because he thinks he has betrayed him. He tries to run but realises that the police have got the place surrounded so he walks up to Inspector Matthews and throws down his gun]
See them?
[camera shows shots of various onlookers]
And them. And them. You can't put the frighteners on *all* of them. Not all the time.
Why not?
You call 'em punters. We call 'em witnesses.
You know, if I looked at one of them, they'd piss in their pants. Because I'm Vic Dakin.
Used to be.
And who are you? What do *you* do? Keeping Britain clean on thirty quid a week. Respect! Respect! You don't know what it is. Unless you're Vic Dakin. Tell 'im, someone, tell 'im.
[no-one says anything to support Vic]
A hundred witnesses. But only twelve men on the jury. You remember that. Only twelve men on the jury.
[more shots of various onlookers and policemen, none of them looking scared]

[shouting]
Who are you looking at?
[Vic has cut Benny's throat and left him dangling from a balcony. His blood starts to drip onto the pavement below and some falls on Vic as he leaves]
Bleeding pigeons.
Drinking, whoring, gambling, pathetic... pathetic... pathetic.
That's a nice dog you got there, Ken. A friend had one like it. It got run over... a few times.
What about Thompson?
He's still on the critical list.
Oh he'll live - just. But he'll live.
Would Dakin be there himself?

*Be* there himself? He'd have *done* it himself. He'd have enjoyed it. He doesn't give a monkeys. Helps him to relax. D'you know what he does on a Sunday, Tom? If it's fine, he takes his mum down to Brighton. Walks round the seafront, up to the pier, buys a plate of whelks. Then drives home at thirty miles an hour so she doesn't get hiccups.
Well, he can't be *all* bad, then, can he?
[Vic and his gang have kidnapped Edgar from hospital - which is exactly what the police were hoping they would do. Binney is tailing Vic who is going to see Edgar]

[gleefully]
I think it's going to be a lovely day.
[Vic's gang have kidnapped Edgar from hospital]
He doesn't seem glad to see us. I mean, there's no enthusiasm. We sprung you, didn't we? Aren't you glad to be out? I mean, where's your gratitude?
I'm sick, Vic. They were going to operate.
*I'll* operate.
[Vic walks towards Edgar and opens his pyjama jacket]
If you don't tell me where that money is in ten seconds, I'll open you OUT!
I haven't said anything. I wouldn't. I mean, you've no worries from me - from this end.
I'm sure you haven't, Mr Brown. I just want to impress on you not to get too silly - not to do anything heroic.
You know me. No fear.
I just wanted to IMPRESS upon you.
[Vic punches Mr Brown in the stomach and then starts kicking him viciously]
